title: Tor Messenger
long_description: A high-security, self-hosted chat system architected for extreme anonymity. The system operates on a 'trustless' federated model: each user runs their own local Flask server, which routes all communication over the Tor network. This local server is responsible for all GPG encryption and decryption, ensuring that unencrypted messages never leave the user's machine.

A central mariaDB server (which anyone can host) manages account registration and friend connections, but it only ever handles encrypted data. It has zero access to message content or user IP addresses. Once a message is delivered and read, it is deleted from the server and stored only on the users' local machines.

This architecture is ideal for activists, journalists, or privacy-critical groups who need to manage their own infrastructure. The main limitation is usability, as it requires users to run their own server. A key technical challenge was building a zero-JavaScript front-end to comply with the Tor Browser's most secure settings.

gallery.caption: Dashboard with friend requests and quick actions.
gallery.description: The entire app is built with zero JavaScript to ensure maximum security within the Tor Browser (which blocks scripts by default). This presented a unique design challenge, requiring all interactions to be handled purely on the backend.

gallery.caption: A secure, end-to-end encrypted chat.
gallery.description: Messages are encrypted locally before being sent, so the central server never sees plain text. For group chats, each message is individually encrypted for every member, maintaining the 'trustless' model.

gallery.caption: Local, encrypted message storage.
gallery.description: This shows the local chat log. Once a message is read, it's deleted from the server and saved locally. Messages you send are stored symmetrically, while others remain asymmetrically encrypted until your private key decrypts them.
